text: in this tutorial we're gonna talk about

this law what's the main idea behind it
well let me give you an example to
illustrate it so let's say if you have a
container with some gas particles and
this is gonna be your rigid container
its volume is fixed what's gonna happen
if you add heat to this container what's
gonna happen to the pressure inside will
the pressure increase or decrease
according to gay lussac's law anytime
you increase the temperature the
pressure will increase if the volume is
held constant if the volume is allowed
to expand proportional to the
temperature then the pressure could be
constant if you have a fixed container
with a fixed volume like a rigid
container if you increase the
temperature then the pressure has to go
up now how does that work exactly well
as you add heat to the molecules these
molecules will gain kinetic energy and
so they will be moving a lot faster at a
higher temperature as a result of the
increased speed they will collide more
frequently with the walls of the
container and anytime you can increase
the number of collisions you will
increase the pressure inside the
container so that's how an increase in
temperature leads to an increase in
pressure higher temperature causes
molecules to move faster which increases
the number of molecular collisions which
leads to a higher pressure so that's the
gist of gay lussac's law temperature and
pressure are directly proportional if
you decrease the temperature the
molecules will lose kinetic energy they
will travel slower and so there's gonna
be less molecular collisions so the
pressure will decrease
now let's plot temperature on the x-axis
and pressure on the y-axis the shape of
the graph is a linear shape it's simply
a straight line going up so make sure

be tested on it on your next exam now
the equation that goes with gay lussac's
law is this equation P 1 over T 1 is
equal to P 2 over T 2 so this is the
formula that you need to use now the
pressure has to be in the same units it
can both be in Torr 8cm kiloPascals PSI
millimeters mercury it simply has to
match now the temperature has to be in

now another illustration of gay lussac's
law at work is if you have a pot so
let's say you have a pot and you put

pressure inside as you heat up water
some of the molecules will vaporize into

buildup of gas above the surface of the
fluid and as the pressure increases
eventually if when it gets hot enough
that pressure will be strong enough to
lift off the lid of the pot and so as
the temperature increases the pressure
will increase and in this example
there's going to be a limit once the
pressure reaches that threshold it will
be strong enough to lift off the pot and
